title: A Phase 3, 12-Week, Multicenter, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, 2-Arm, Fixed-dose Trial to Evaluate the Efficacy, Safety, and Tolerability of Brexpiprazole (OPC-34712) in the Treatment of Subjects With Agitation Associated With Dementia of the Alzheimer's Type
description_brief: This study compares the efficacy of 2 doses of brexpiprazole with placebo in participants with agitation associated with dementia of the Alzheimer's type.
description_detailed: This is a phase 3, 12-week, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, fixed-dose trial designed to assess the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of brexpiprazole compared with placebo. The trial consists of a 12-week double-blind treatment period with a 30 day follow-up. The trial population will include male and female participants between 55 and 90 years of age (inclusive) with a diagnosis of probable Alzheimer's disease, who are residing either in an institutionalized setting or in a non-institutionalized setting where the participant is not living alone. This trial will analyze data gathered from approximately 330 participants at multiple countries. Participants may also be eligible to enter an active treatment extension trial.

participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: A total of 345 participants were randomized, and participated in the study from 16 May 2018 to 1 June 2022.

groups.title: Brexpiprazole 2 mg
groups.description: Participants followed a titration schedule, to gradually increase their dose from 0.5 milligrams per day (mg/day) in the starting to 2 mg/day from Day 15. Participants continued to receive brexpiprazole 2 milligrams (mg), once daily until Week 12.

groups.title: Brexpiprazole 3 mg
groups.description: Participants followed a titration schedule, to gradually increase their dose from 0.5 mg/day in the starting to 3 mg/day from Day 29. Participants continued to receive brexpiprazole 3 mg, once daily until Week 12.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Participants received matching placebo, once daily for 12 weeks.

milestones.comment: Intent-to-treat (ITT) Population consisted of all participants in the randomized sample, who took at least 1 dose of investigational medical product (IMP) and had a baseline and at least one post-baseline evaluation for the Cohen-Mansfield Agitation Inventory (CMAI) total score.

measures.title: Cohen-Mansfield Agitation Inventory (CMAI) Total Score
measures.description: The CMAI assesses frequency of agitated behaviors in elderly persons. The scale consists of 29 agitated behaviors that are further categorized into distinct agitation syndromes, also known as CMAI factors of agitation. Each of the agitated behaviors are scored 1 (never) to 7 (several times an hours), with the total scale score ranging from 29 to 203. Higher score indicates greater frequency of agitated behavior.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline to Week 12 in the CMAI Total Score
outcomeMeasures.description: The CMAI score is used to assess the frequency of manifestations of agitated behaviors in participants. The CMAI consists of 29 agitated behaviors that are rated on a 7-point scale of frequency across four subscales of aggressive behavior, physically nonaggressive behavior, verbally agitated behavior and hiding and hoarding as: 1=never; 2=less than once a week; 3=once or twice a week; 4=several times a week; 5=once or twice a day; 6=several times a day; 7=several times an hour. The CMAI total score ranges from 29 to 203. Higher scores indicate worsening of the condition. A negative change from baseline indicates improvement. Mixed model repeated measures (MMRM) was used for the analysis. As prespecified in the statistical analysis plan (SAP), data for this outcome measure was analyzed and reported in a combined way for brexpiprazole 2 and 3 mg.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The ITT Population consisted of all participants in the randomized sample, who took at least 1 dose of IMP and had a baseline and at least one post-baseline evaluation for the CMAI total score. Overall number analyzed is the number of participants with data available for analyses.

groups.title: Brexpiprazole 2 and 3 mg
groups.description:
Participants followed a titration schedule, to gradually increase their dose from 0.5 mg/day in the starting to 2 mg/day from Day 15 or from 0.5 mg/day in the starting to 3 mg/day from Day 29.

Participants continued to receive brexpiprazole 2 or 3 mg, once daily until Week 12.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Participants received matching placebo, once daily for 12 weeks.

analyses.pValueComment: MMRM method with model terms of treatment, trial site, visit, treatment-by-visit and baseline-by-visit interaction were used for analysis.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline to Week 12 in the Clinical Global Impression Severity of Illness (CGI-S) Score, as Related to Agitation
outcomeMeasures.description: CGI-S was used to rate the severity of agitation. The score ranges from 0 to 7 with response choices as, 0=not assessed; 1=normal, not at all ill; 2=borderline mentally ill; 3=mildly ill; 4=moderately ill; 5=markedly ill; 6=severely ill; and 7=among the most extremely ill participants. The higher the value, the more severe the agitation. A negative change from baseline indicates improvement. MMRM was used for the analysis. As prespecified in the SAP, data for this outcome measure was analyzed and reported in a combined way for brexpiprazole 2 and 3 mg.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The ITT Population consisted of all participants in the randomized sample, who took at least 1 dose of IMP and had a baseline and at least one post-baseline evaluation for the CMAI total score. Overall number analyzed is the number of participants with data available for analyses.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline to Week 12 in CMAI Subscale Scores
outcomeMeasures.description: The CMAI score is used to assess the frequency of manifestations of agitated behaviors in participants. It consists of 29 agitated behaviors that are rated on a 7-point scale of frequency across four subscales of aggressive behavior, physically nonaggressive behavior, verbally agitated behavior and hiding and hoarding, as: 1=never; 2=less than once a week; 3=once or twice a week; 4=several times a week; 5=once or twice a day; 6=several times a day; 7=several times an hour. The four subscales include 12, 6, 4, and 2 items, respectively. The score of the subscale is the sum of the individual items included in the subscale, so the score range for each of the 4 subscales is 0 to 84, 0 to 42, 0 to 28, and 0 to 14, respectively. Higher scores indicate worsening of the condition. A negative change from baseline=improvement. MMRM was used for the analysis. As prespecified in the SAP, data for this outcome measure was analyzed and reported in a combined way for brexpiprazole 2 and 3 mg.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The ITT Population consisted of all participants in the randomized sample, who took at least 1 dose of IMP and had a baseline and at least one post-baseline evaluation for the CMAI total score. Overall number analyzed is the number of participants with data available for analyses.

outcomeMeasures.title: Clinical Global Impressions-Improvement (CGI-I) Score at Each Trial Visit During the Double-Blind Treatment Period
outcomeMeasures.description: CGI-I is a 7-point scale that requires the clinician to assess whether a participant's condition has improved or worsened relative to a baseline state at the beginning of the intervention. This was rated as: 1=very much improved; 2=much improved; 3=minimally improved; 4=no change; 5=minimally worse; 6=much worse; or 7=very much worse. Higher scores indicate worse condition. As prespecified in the SAP, data for this outcome measure was analyzed and reported in a combined way for brexpiprazole 2 and 3 mg.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The ITT Population consisted of all participants in the randomized sample, who took at least 1 dose of IMP and had a baseline and at least one post-baseline evaluation for the CMAI total score. Overall number analyzed is the number of participants with data available for analyses. Number analyzed is the number of participants with data available for analysis at the specified time point.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: From signing of informed consent up to end of study (Week 16)
adverseEventsModule.description: Randomized Sample was used to assess all-cause mortality. It consisted of all participants who were randomized into this trial. Safety Sample was used to assess serious adverse events (SAEs) and other adverse events (AEs) and consisted of all participants who were administered at least one dose of IMP.

certainAgreement.otherDetails: Sponsor reserves the right to review results publications prior to public release and can delay such publications for a period greater than 60 days but no more than 120 days from the date that the publication is submitted to the Sponsor for review. Sponsor can require changes to the publication to protect Sponsor's intellectual property rights and/or confidential information and reserves the right to limit publication timing and scope of data published based on the number of study locations.

drug: brexpiprazole (OPC-34712; brand name Rexulti) — atypical antipsychotic; serotonin–dopamine activity modulator (partial agonist at D2/D3 and 5-HT1A; antagonist at 5-HT2A and certain adrenergic receptors). citeturn2search3turn2search0
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests brexpiprazole versus placebo to treat "agitation associated with dementia of the Alzheimer's type," i.e., a behavioral/neuropsychiatric symptom rather than a disease‑modifying or cognition‑targeted outcome (primary endpoint: agitation scales). citeturn0search2turn0search3

Act: Key extracted details — drug: brexpiprazole (OPC‑34712, marketed as Rexulti), an atypical antipsychotic / serotonin‑dopamine activity modulator; intervention aims to reduce agitation symptoms, not to target amyloid/tau or improve underlying Alzheimer's pathology. Trial design: randomized, double‑blind, fixed‑dose (2 doses) vs placebo over 12 weeks. citeturn1search0turn0search2

Web search results (selected sources used): JAMA Neurology / PMC full report of the phase 3 agitation trial showing brexpiprazole reduced agitation vs placebo. citeturn0search2; PubMed summary of placebo‑controlled trials of brexpiprazole in agitation associated with Alzheimer dementia. citeturn0search3; FDA press release for supplemental approval of Rexulti for agitation associated with dementia due to Alzheimer’s disease (May 11, 2023). citeturn1search0; preclinical/in vitro characterization and pharmacology of brexpiprazole describing its receptor profile. citeturn2search3turn2search0

Reflect: Classification check — fits the definition of 'Neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' because the drug is an antipsychotic used to treat agitation (a neuropsychiatric/behavioral symptom) in Alzheimer’s dementia rather than aiming to modify disease pathology or directly enhance cognition. The FDA has approved brexpiprazole (Rexulti) for this indication based on these trials, which supports the classification. citeturn1search0turn0search2

Notes on ambiguity/missing info: None critical — the trial title/description explicitly states agitation treatment and names brexpiprazole (OPC‑34712). Mechanistic details of brexpiprazole were confirmed from pharmacology sources. citeturn2search3turn0search2
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is brexpiprazole (Rexulti), an atypical antipsychotic / serotonin–dopamine activity modulator that acts via neurotransmitter receptors (partial agonist at dopamine D2/D3 and serotonin 5-HT1A; antagonist at 5-HT2A), and the trial’s objective is to reduce agitation (a neuropsychiatric symptom) rather than to modify Alzheimer’s pathology. citeturn0search3turn0search0

Act: Extracted details — drug: brexpiprazole (OPC‑34712, Rexulti). Mechanism: serotonin and dopamine receptor modulation (D2/D3 partial agonist, 5‑HT1A partial agonist, 5‑HT2A antagonist). Indication/trial focus: treatment of agitation associated with dementia due to Alzheimer’s disease in a 12‑week, randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled, fixed‑dose Phase 3 design. These facts point to a neurotransmitter‑receptor mechanism for a symptomatic (neuropsychiatric) indication. citeturn0search3turn0search0turn0search2

Reflect: Classification check — CADRO category D) Neurotransmitter Receptors best fits because the drug’s known pharmacology targets monoaminergic (dopamine/serotonin) receptors and the trial aims to treat behavioral symptoms (agitation) rather than amyloid/tau, inflammation, synaptic repair, or other disease‑modifying pathways. The trial’s published Phase 3 results and FDA supplemental approval for this symptom support this interpretation. No important alternative CADRO category (e.g., multi-target or Other) is more specific here. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Web sources used: FDA press release (supplemental approval for Rexulti for agitation associated with dementia due to Alzheimer’s disease); Lundbeck/Otsuka and BusinessWire summaries and JAMA Neurology Phase 3 reporting; manufacturer pharmacology summaries describing brexpiprazole’s receptor profile. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search2
